title: Documentation
subtitle: Learn how to use BeCoMe for expert opinion aggregation

gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.intro: BeCoMe helps you aggregate expert opinions expressed as fuzzy triangular numbers. Here's how to get started:

createProject.title: Creating a Project
createProject.step1: Sign up or log in to your account
createProject.step2: Click "New Project" on the Projects page
createProject.step3: Enter a project name and description
createProject.step4: Set the scale: minimum value, maximum value, and unit (e.g., 0-100 CZK billions)

inviteExperts.title: Inviting Experts
inviteExperts.description: Only registered users can be invited as experts.
inviteExperts.step3: Enter the email of a registered user
inviteExperts.step4: They will see the invitation in their "Invitations" tab

expertOpinions.title: Entering Expert Opinions
expertOpinions.intro: Experts answer the raised question by assessing a quantitative parameter. They can express their responses in three ways:

crisp.title: Crisp Number
crisp.description: A single precise value when the expert is confident about their estimate. In the interface, simply enter the same value for all three fields (Lower = Peak = Upper).
crisp.example: Example: If you're certain the budget should be exactly 50 billion CZK, enter (50, 50, 50).

fuzzy.title: Fuzzy Triangular Number
fuzzy.description: A triangular membership function with three values representing uncertainty. This is the most common input format.
fuzzy.lower: Lower bound (pessimistic estimate) - the minimum realistic value
fuzzy.peak: Peak (most likely value) - your best estimate
fuzzy.upper: Upper bound (optimistic estimate) - the maximum realistic value
fuzzy.example: Example: If you think the budget should be around 60 billion, but could realistically be between 40 and 80, enter (40, 60, 80).
fuzzy.rule: Values must satisfy: Lower ≤ Peak ≤ Upper

likert.title: Likert Scale
likert.description: For agreement/disagreement questions, use linguistic terms mapped to numeric values:
likert.example: Example: If you "Rather agree", you might enter (60, 75, 90) to express your position with some uncertainty.

results.title: Understanding Results
results.intro: After experts submit their opinions, BeCoMe calculates the optimal group decision.

bestCompromise.title: Best Compromise (ΓΩMean)
bestCompromise.description: The optimal aggregation of all expert opinions. It combines the arithmetic mean (Γ) and median (Ω) to find the value that best represents the group consensus.
bestCompromise.centroid: The centroid is the "center of gravity" of the triangular number - a single value representing the overall estimate.

arithmeticMean.title: Arithmetic Mean (Γ)
arithmeticMean.description: The component-wise average of all expert opinions. Each component (lower, peak, upper) is averaged separately.

median.title: Median (Ω)
median.description: The middle value when opinions are sorted by centroid. More robust against extreme outliers than the mean.

maxError.title: Maximum Error (Δmax)
maxError.description: A quality metric indicating the uncertainty level of the compromise. Lower values indicate better agreement among experts.
maxError.interpretation: If max error is high relative to the scale, it suggests significant disagreement among experts.

visualization.title: Reading the Visualization
visualization.description: The triangle chart shows all fuzzy numbers on the same scale:

elements.yAxis: Y-axis: membership degree (0-1, where 1 is most certain)

visualization.tip: Toggle "Show individual opinions" to see how each expert's opinion compares to the aggregated result.

fuzzyNumber.definition: A number represented by three values (lower, peak, upper) forming a triangle. Expresses uncertainty in expert estimates.

centroid.definition: The center of gravity of a triangular number. Calculated as (lower + peak + upper) / 3.

membership.definition: A function that assigns a degree of membership (0-1) to each value. For triangular numbers, the peak has membership 1, and it decreases linearly to 0 at the bounds.

aggregation.definition: The process of combining multiple expert opinions into a single representative value.
